messageBody:
Hi Elliote,

On 1/24/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> Subscribers to this mailing list might be interest in an ongoing
> discussion on The Cafes about Experimental Programming:
>
> http://cafe.elharo.com/java/experimental-programming/
>
> In brief, I relate the story of a bug fix in XOM, and argue for the
> primacy of testing and experiment over claimed understanding of code.


I think this is a very bad idea.

The first fix should have been a warning to you: you made a quick change,
thought you were done, shipped the new version and then someone else pointed
out that your fix had created a deeper, more subtle bug.

Instead of learning the obvious lesson from that mistake (which is "try to
understand the code you are modifying"), you repeat it and fix the second
bug with another one-line hack without any good reason, using the
justification "the tests are passing, so I'm okay".

Well, yes, if you assume that your tests are 100% perfect. They were not
the first time, why do you assume they are now?

To make matter worse, you claim:

I think some of the people posting here don't realize just how comprehensive
XOM's test suite is.

Don't you have enough proof that you are overestimating the
comprehensiveness of these tests since they failed to catch two bugs in a
short period of time?

Note that I totally understand the necessity to do "hack fixing" when
circumstances warrant it (deadlines, pressing customer, etc...), but
recommending it as a new way of development is irresponsible.

But I guess the best illustration of this point is the following comment
from one of your readers:

I'm having a serious rethink about using XOM.

--
Cédric
